Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative: A privacy-preserving contact tracing system for COVID-19 containment and mitigation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
A crucial tool in the fight with COVID-19 is a contact tracing system that can identify individuals who had close contacts with confirmed cases in the past. Such a mechanism can alarm these individuals so that they can voluntarily self-quarantine. In addition, when these individuals start to have symptoms, a contact tracing system can prioritize them for testing, which will make more efficient use of the limited test capacity and provide early treatment for infected individuals. However, due to strict privacy-protection laws in US and many western countries, it is a challenge to deploy such a system. To solve this urgent problem, this project builds a privacy-preserving contact tracing system, named COVID Detector. COVID Detector relies on smartphones to track both patient and healthy person's past locations and leverages cryptographic computations to ensure that no private data is exposed during the contact tracing computation. This project addresses the broader need to support, in a privacy-friendly manner, user contact tracing in a modern, complex and highly-connected world. This discussion is presently highly relevant in the context of balancing public health and individual user privacy.


While there are a few existing contact tracing apps for COVID-19, anonymity of user/patient identity is the best that they can provide to protect user privacy. COVID Detector is the first that provides strong protection of both user/patient identity and user/patient trajectory data. COVID-Detector uses homomorphic encryption techniques to match the trajectory of confirmed COVID-19 patients with that of healthy users in the ciphertext domain, so that healthy users can determine their infection risk level. The matching process reveals neither healthy users' nor patients' location data to any party. The use of homomorphic encryption technologies in trajectory tracking is novel and has not been applied before.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A crucial tool in the fight with COVID-19 is a contact tracing system that can identify individuals whohad close contacts with confirmed cases in the past. Such a mechanism can alarm these individuals so thatthey can voluntarily self-quarantine. In addition, when these individuals start to have symptoms, acontact tracing system can prioritize them for testing, which will make more efficient use of the limitedtest capacity and provide early treatment for infected individuals. However, due to strict privacyprotectionlaws in US and many western countries, it has been a challenge to deploy such a system.

This project investigates protocols suitable for digital contact tracing. Two over-arching considerations are made during the development of the protocol. First, the digital contact tracing protocol must be compatible with the existing, prevalent manual contact tracing protocol which is based on interview with potentially infected patients. Second, the digital contact tracing protocol must preserve the privacy of the patient, as well as of the healthy users of the contact tracing app.

This project develops a digital contact-tracing protocol called KHOVID, which aims at addressing these goals. First, the project develops a protocol that uses two privacy-friendly cryptographic techniques, to ensure that any data collected from a mobile phone remains private. This protocol can record and compare location data in a privacy-friendly manner. This project develops prototype software and simulations to study the feasibility of such a protocol. Second, the project implements several surveys to study the adoption of digital contact tracing app with a target audience. The investigators chose two universities, Worcester Polytechnic Institute and Virginia Tech, to implement this survey. The project also makes an extensive survey of existing digital contact-tracing techniques in order to compare the strenght and weaknesses of each. 

In terms of outreach, the project collaborates with a local high-school student to develop a Python-based simulation of pedestrian traffic. Such a simulation is used to study the contact time of persons in a confined environment. In addition, the simulation provides insight into the effect of contact tracing app adoption rate. The simulation will be the basis of future research efforts by data science undergraduate students at the PI's institution.
